DOI: 10.1039/x0xx00000x

Xiaodong Zhang, Tao Sun and Xin-Long Ni*
Cucurbit[8]uril (Q[8] or CB[8]), as a synthetic macrocyclic host, play an important role in constructing various water soluble dynamic  supramolecular  polymers  and  materials.  Here  we  report  host-guest  interactions  of  Q[8]  with π-conjugated bispyridinium guests in aqueous solution that resulted in a series of unprecedented dynamic 2:2, 2:3, and 1:2 assemblies (guest/Q[8]).  Most  importantly,  these  subtly  different  host-guest  binding  modes  could  be  distinguished  by  naked-eye observation of the resulting quantitative fluorescence emissions. Further characterization suggested that the Q[8] hoststabilized charge-transfer interactionscould be dissociated and controlled by the N-substituted alkyl chains on the cationic guests via the formation of 2:3quinary complex or U-shaped conformation, which leading to the discovery of new possible binding fashions for the Q[8] host.

fluorescent signals for monitoring of the accompanying dynamic host-guest interactions.
Cucurbit[8]uril  (Q[8]  or  CB[8]), 1,  2   a  large  homologue  of  the cucurbituril  family,  is  unique  because  of  its  ability  to  form ternary  complexes  by  encapsulating  two  hetero-  or  homoguests in its rigid macrocyclic  cavity. In particular, hoststabilized charge-transfer (HSCT), 3  as the dominant interaction force, has resulted in the wide use of Q[8] to construct various water soluble dynamic materials in the past decade. 4-15 Meanwhile,  it  was  also  found  that  Q[8]  is  able  to  act  as molecular handcuffs to simultaneously include two chromophore dyes in its cavity to form dimer assemly. This not only increases the π-π stacking of the aromatic moieties, 16  but also  enhances  intra/inter-molecular  charge  transfer  (ICT)  of the inclusion guest dyes. 17
Recently, it was discovered that π-conjugated bispyridinium derivatives could serve as both electrondeficient  and  electron-rich  groups  that  could  dimerize  inside the  Q[8]  cavity  to  form  highly  stable  Q[8]-enhanced  ternary complexes 18-20 and supramolecular polymers 21-23 with enhanced light efficiency. More recently, Scherman's group, 2426 Schalley's group, 27 and Ma's group 28 revealed that complexation  of  diaryl  viologens  bearing  electron-donating groups  with  Q[8]  could  be  used  to  form  a  series  of  unique dimer emissions in 2:2 binding mode. These studies indicated the  potential  of  Q[8]  as  a  host  in  the  fabrication  of  smart tunable  luminescent  materials.  However,  to  our  knowledge, there is few attention in Q[8] encapsulation-triggered

Fluorescence  has  been  widely  used  to  explore  dynamic processes,  such  as  self-assembly, 29,30   molecular  motion 31 and conformational changes. 32  The high sensitivity of fluorescence methods allows for tracking of molecular interactions even at nanomolar  concentrations.  In particular, it is possible to visualize directly and in real time to monitor processes in situ. For example, Tang et al. exploited aggregation-induced emission fluorescent imaging to successfully demonstrate the transition processes of surfactant micelles and microemulsion droplets. 33  Li and co-workers directly observed the distribution of  gelatin  in  calcium  carbonate  crystals  by  super-resolution fluorescence microscopy. 34  Yang et al. found that the process and  dynamics  of  coordination-driven  self-assembly  could  be tracked in real-time by fluorescence-resonance energy transfer. 35
In this work, a series of different length alkyl chains were introduced  into π-conjugated bispyridinium  species  as  guest molecule  (Scheme  1).  We  found  that  the  alkyl  chains  as  the terminal moieties played a crucial role in driving the Q[8] host to  form  various  dynamic  host-guest  assemblies including 2:2, 2:3,  and  1:2  assemblies.  In  particular,  the  multiple  dynamic Q[8]-based  host-guest  interactions  could  be  distinguished  by naked-eye observation of the resulting quantitative fluorescence emissions. Further studies revealed that the Q[8]based  HSCT  interaction  could  be  dissociated  or  controlled bythe alkyl chain lengthsand the slightly modification of the πconjugated aromatic core of the guests.

Scheme 1. Chemical structures of OPV 2+ derivatives and Q[8], and representation of Q[8]-based dynamic host-guest assemblies with multiple tunable fluorescent signals. Route 1: Q[8] concentrations dependent host-guest interactions of 2:1, 2:2, 2:3, and 1:2 (guest/Q[8]); route 2: the formtion of U-shaped conformation of Q[8] with OPV 2+ -2Me (7C-9C).

Our previous work revealed that the photophysical properties of oligo( p -phenylenevinylene) ( OPV 2+ )-based bispyridinium guest  molecules  could  be  sensitively  switched  by  the  Q[8] host. 21 Here, to conveniently monitor multimodular host-guest assemblies of Q[8] with the alkyl chain-appended guests, the π-conjugated OPV 2+ core  was  selected  as  the  fluorescent reporting moiety. In order to capture and distinguish dynamic host-guest  interactions,  such  as  whether  the  Q[8]  host  could enclose  the  phenyl  part  of  the  guest,  larger  barrier  groups, such as one or two methyl (Me) groups, were appended to the phenyl moiety to serve as a 'brake.' The molecular structure of guests together with plausible fluorescent visible host-guest assemblies  are  shown  in  Scheme  1.  Guests OPV 2+ -H , OPV 2+ Me , and OPV 2+ -2Me with  different  alkyl  chains  (containing carbon atoms from 1C to 9C), in which I -  as counter anions for 1C  appended  guests,  and  Br as  counter  anions  for  other guests.The  related  guests  hereafter  abbreviated  as OPV 2+ - H, ( Me, 2Me ) (1C to 9C).
The fluorescence and UV-vis spectra of the guests appeared similar emission peak around 480 nm and absorption peak around 390 nm  in aqueous solution, respectively, indicating  that  the  appended  alkyl  chains  did  not  affect  the optical  properties  of  the OPV 2+ core.  In  the  presence  of  Q[8] host, OPV 2+ -H and OPV 2+ -Me derived guests appeared similar optical  response,  while  some  different  fluorescent  response behaviour  was  observed  in  the  case  of OPV 2+ -2Me based guests  (Fig  1,  Figs.  S1-S3  and  Table  S1).  For  example,  an enhanced  bathochromic  fluorescent  emission  (yellow  colour) shift  was  observed  for  all  of  the  guest  solutions  when  the concentration  of  Q[8]  was  fixed  at  0.5  eq.,  except  for  the OPV 2+ -2Me guests (7C-9C), where slight red-shifts were noted

(Figs.  1f  ).  When  the  concentration  of  Q[8]  was  increased  to 1.0  eq.,  considerably  enhanced  emission  around  at  550  nm was  observed  (Fig.  1a,  1d,  and  Fig.  S1),  except  for  guests OPV 2+ -H (2C-9C), where a tunable enhanced blue-shift emission was seen (Fig. S1 and Table S1).
As the concentration of Q[8] was increased to 1.5 eq., no changes in the fluorescence spectra were observed for any of the 1C-4C appended guests (Fig. S1 and Table S1). However, OPV 2+ -H guests (5C-6C)  (Fig. 1b) and OPV 2+ -Me (5C-6C) underwent  significant  red-shift  emissions  (Table  S1),  and  a blue-shift  emission  changed  was  observed  in  the OPV 2+ -2Me (5C-6C) solution (Figs. 1e).
Interestingly, OPV 2+ -H guests (7C-9C) and OPV 2+ -Me (7C9C) exhibited blue-shift with enhanced emission intensity (Fig. 1c and Table S1), and a slight red-shift of OPV 2+ -2Me (7C-9C) in  the  case  of  concentrations of Q[8] was increased from 0.5 eq. to 2.0 eq., respectively (Figs. 1f and Table S1). Essentially, the different fluorescent responses of the same alkyl-attached guests when Q[8] was added is attributed to modification by the Me group on the OPV 2+ core (Scheme 1).

Compared to the multiple fluorescent signals triggered by different  concentrations  of  Q[8]  host,  similar  changes  in  the UV-vis absorption spectra were observed (Figs. S2-S3). At first glance, all of the maximum absorbance peaks of the guests at 390 nm decreased remarkably, with bathochromic shift of the band  at 400-470 nm  in  the  presence  of  Q[8]  host.  Close inspection revealed considerably enhanced red-shifted absorbance peaks for OPV 2+ -H (5C-6C) and OPV 2+ -Me (5C-6C) guests with two isoabsorption points around 413 and 432 nm, and  enhanced  blue-shifted  absorbance  peaks  (but  still  redshifted compared to the free guest) with isoabsorption points around 428 and 441 nm for OPV 2+ -2Me (5C-6C) guests.

Fig.1 Fluorescence spectrum changes of OPV 2+ core based guests (a-c) OPV 2+ -H (1C, 5C, 9C), (d-f) OPV 2+ -2Me (1C, 5C, 9C) (each of 10.0 µM in aqueous solution, pH 7.2) in the presence of increasing concentrations of Q[8] host, respectively. ( λ ex = 400 nm)
Generally,  guest  complexation  within  the  cavity  of  Q[8] typically results in an upfield shift of the encapsulated protons (shielding  effect  of  the  hydrophobic  cavity)  and  a  downfield shift  of  protons  in  close  proximity  to  the  portals  of  the  host (deshielding effect of the carbonyl-rimmed portal). For example, upon titration of 0.5 eq. Q[8] into a guest OPV 2+ -H (1C)  solution  (neutral  D2O),  nearly  all  of  the  protons  on  the parent OPV 2+ core underwent upfield shifts (Fig. 2a). Particular protons  on  the  ethylene  moieties  and  the  phenyl  group, including the methyl groups on the OPV 2+ -Me and OPV 2+ -2Me guests (Figs. S4-S7, apart from OPV 2+ -2Me (7C-9C), which will be  discussed  later  on),  were  upfield  shifted  significantly.  In contrast,  no  obvious  proton  chemical  shift  changes  were observed  for  the  N-substituted  alkyl  chains.  These  results indicated that the phenyl aromatic and ethylene moieties were encapsulated in the Q[8] cavity to form 2:1 host-guest complexes  (guest/Q[8]). 21   It  is  believed  that  the  Q[8]  host  is threaded onto the guests such that it can move back and forth along the aromatic OPV 2+ core of the guests. In particular, ion dipole  interactions  between  the  positively  charged  nitrogen atoms of the guests and the carbonyl oxygen atoms of the Q[8] host  prevent  dissociation.  This  shuttling  motion  is  relatively fast on the NMR time scale, so all of the signals for the protons

1
Fig. 3  H NMR spectra of Q[8]/
OPV 2+ -H
(1C-9C) at a molar ratio of 2:2.
on the aromatic core are shifted upfield in the spectrum, and no  proton  chemical  shift  changes  are  observed  for  the  Nsubstituted  alkyl  chains.  Similar  proton  signal  changes  were apparent  in  the  host-guest  complexes  of OPV 2+ -Me (Fig.  S5) and OPV 2+ -2Me (Fig.  S6)  systems,  but  less  upfield  shift  was observed for the protons on the OPV 2+ core (Fig. S7), suggesting that the barrier Me and 2Me groups on the phenyl moiety  as  'brakes'  slowed  the  rate  of  the  Q[8]  shuttling motion.
As  an  example,  2D  NMR  spectra  such  as 1 H1 H  NOESY (nuclear  Overhauser  effect  spectroscopy)  of  Q[8]  with  guest OPV 2+ -H (1C)  showed NOE correlation of Hd'-Ha',  implying  the formation of head-to-tail dimer complexes (Fig. 2b). Therefore, complexation  inside  the  confined  space  of  the  Q[8]  cavity results in distinct π-π stacking (substantial electron-

delocalization due to dimeric stacking along the long molecular axis), which  leads  to  the  significant  red-shift  fluorescence emission (yellow colour) as mentioned in Fig. 1. Compared to the shorter fluorescence life time (around 0.13 ns) and lower quantum  yield  (around  5%)  of  those  free  guests,  all  of  the Q[8]-encapsulated  guest  assemblies  in  solution  had  a  long lifetime of 11-15 ns (Table S2) and an enhanced quantum yield (Table S3), apart from OPV 2+ -H (7C-9C), where the fluorescence lifetime was 6.7-8.6 ns. This may be attributed to the long alkyl chain placing the π-conjugated OPV 2+ fluorophore  near  to  the  Q[8]  carbonyl  portals,  which  was confirmed  by  the  lower  upfield  chemical  shift  of  the  phenyl protons of OPV 2+ -H (7C-9C) (Fig. S7a).

As the concentration of Q[8] was increased to ~1.0 eq., for OPV 2+ -H guests,  the  signals  for  all  guest  protons,  including those  of  theN-substituted  alkyl  chains,  were  located  in  the upfield area (Figs. 2 and S4). Protons on the pyridinium (Hd and He) appeared  to  be  shifted  further  upfield, whereas  the ethylene  protons  were  still  in  the  same  position  and  phenyl protons were shifted downfield (still upfield shifted compared to the free guest). The NOE correlations between He''-Hc'', He''Ha'' , and Ha''-Hd'', (Fig. 2c) indicated that a dynamic 2:2 complex was  formed  in  this  process.  Interestingly,  closer  inspection revealed  that  the  Hd  and  He  protons  exhibited  a  gradual downfield shift as the length of the N-substituted alkyl chains increased (Fig. 3). In particular, for OPV 2+ -H (7C-9C) guests, it was  observed  that  the  signal  for  Hd  underwent  a  downfield shift  compared  to  0.5  eq.  of  Q[8]  (Hd  was  even  downfield shifted, to 7.98 ppm  from  7.90  ppm  in  the  free  state, suggesting that Hd was in close proximity to the Q[8] portal). This result indicated that the longer alkyl chains might play an important role in switching the dynamic 2:2 host-guest complex from head-to-tail geometries to head-to-head arrangements,  which  is  also  supported  by  the  fluorescence spectra  changes  (weak  intensity  around  at  550  nm)  and shorter  life  time  (Table  S2).  Similar  NMR  and  fluorescence spectra  changes  were  observed  in  the OPV 2+ -Me and OPV 2+ 2Me systems , suggesting  similar  host-guest  assembly  modes. However,  the  significant  proton  downfield  shift  of  the  Me group  and  strong  fluorescence  intensity  around  555  nm  for OPV 2+ -2Me (1C-6C) implied that the double Me moieties can control and retard the shuttling rate of Q[8] on the guest and favor the head-to-tail complex (Fig. S7c).

Upon increasing the concentration of Q[8] up to 1.5 eq., no further chemical shift changes of the protons were observed in any of the 1C-4C-appended host-guest complexes. However, the proton peaks of the ethylene (Hb and Hc), phenyl (Ha) moieties and the alkyl chains on the 5C-6C-based OPV 2+ -H and OPV 2+ -Me guests,  including  the  monomer  Me  group  on OPV 2+ -Me , exhibited significant upfield shifts (Figs. 4a and S4S5).  The  signals  of  the  other  protons,  such  as  Hd and  He, exhibited  slightly  downfield  shifts  compared  to  1.0  eq.  Q[8], but were still upfield relative to their original positions in the free state. There were no further proton peak shifts when the concentration of Q[8] was increased above 1.5 eq. The 2D NOE

Journal Name correlations for OPV 2+ -H (5C) (He'-Hc', Hd'-Ha', He'-H5', He'-H4', Hd'H2', Hd'-H1', H1'-H4', H2'-H5', and H2'-H4'), suggested a unique 2:3 assembly of the guests with Q[8] 36  (Figs. 4b and S9-10). From a structural viewpoint, this binding mode would strengthen the acceptor-donor-acceptor (A-D-A) electronic interaction of the π -conjugated OPV 2+ -derived cationic guest. Especially, the central  Q[8]  encapsulation  of  the  dimeric  guest  not  only increases  the π-surface of  the OPV 2+ core,  but  also  greatly enhances the  electron-donor  group  promoting  the  ICT  effect of  the  guest.  Therefore,  a  further  red-shifted  emission  was observed in that host-guest system.
In contrast, in the case of OPV 2+ -2Me (5C-6C), it was found that the signals for protons on the ethylene and phenyl groups (including the two Me groups on the phenyl parent) underwent  downfield  shifts  even  compared  to  their  original proton  peaks  in  the  free  guest  (Fig.  S6),  suggesting  that  the moieties were located at the carbonyl portals of the Q[8] host. The  proton  signals  of  the  pyridinium  and  the  alkyl  chains exhibited remarkable upfield shifts, implying that these groups were  deep  in  the  Q[8]  cavity.  The  detailed 1 H  NMR  titration experiment results revealed that a 1:2 host-guest interaction (Q[8]/guest) was formed in this system  as well as with all of the 7C-9C appended guests (Figs. S4-S6).

Interestingly, the NOE correlations (Ha'-H9', He'-H5', He'-H4', He'-H3', and Hb'-H9') from the 1:2 complex of OPV 2+ -H (9C) (Fig. 5)  provided  evidence  that  the  N-substituted  alkyl  chain  was folded into the cavity of Q[8] to form a U-shaped conformation together  with  partial  inclusion  the  pyridinium  moiety.  This  is slightly different to the observation by Kim, 37  where the alkyl chains  directly  adopted  the  U-shape  themselves  in  the  Q[8] cavity. In addition, for OPV 2+ -2Me (7C-9C) guests (Fig. S6), the NMR titration results demonstrated that all the signals of the guest protons were upfield shifted from the initial concentration  of  Q[8]  (below  1.0  eq.).  The  proton  peaks  for the  Me  and  parent  phenyl  moieties  were  downfield  shifted when  the  concentration  of  Q[8]  was  increased  from  1.0-2.0 eq.  In  particular,  the  continued  upfield  shifts  of  the  proton signals  for  the  alkyl  chains  and  the  pyridinium  groups  in  the NMR  spectra  suggested  that  no  ternary  complexes  were formed throughout the Q[8] titration. This result implied that there were no π-π interactions between the OPV 2+ -2Me (7C9C) guestsin the Q[8] cavity (Fig. S12), which is consistent with the  observation  from  the  fluorescence  emission  (Fig.  1f). Evidently,  the  two  Me  groups  on  the  phenyl  of  these  guests was  the  key  factor  in  controlling  such  molecular  assembly modes.

Recently, Scherman and co-workers described pioneering work  exploring  the  properties  of  Q[8]-based  complexes  by isothermal  titration  calorimetry  (ITC).  Their  studies  revealed that  the  enthalpies  of  the  2:2  quaternary  complexes  of  Q[8] with  guest  were  typically  below  -50  kJ  mol -1 . 24   The  large binding  enthalpies  can  be  attributed  to  occupation  of  the whole  Q[8]  cavity  by  guest  to  release  the  cavity-bound  high energy water. 38  In an effort to gain more detailed information on  the  binding  interactions  between  Q[8]  and  the OPV 2+ -derived guests, ITC studies were also carried out in this work. As  shown  in  Table  S4,  the  obtained  enthalpy  data  from representative guests were found to range from -95 kJ mol -1  to -50  kJ  mol -1 , suggesting  that  the  Q[8]  cavities  were  fully occupied by guests, except for OPV 2+ -Me (1C)/Q[8] and OPV 2+ 2Me (1C)/Q[8]  complexes,  where  the  enthalpies  were  below40  kJ  mol -1 .  This  can  be  attributed  to  the  Me  group  and shorter alkyl chain making the guest less included in the Q[8] cavity  and  leading  to  less  displacement  of  high  energy  water molecules from the cavity. Similarly,  the  much  lower  binding enthalpies of OPV 2+ -H (5C)/Q[8] (-95.12 kJ mol -1 )  and OPV 2+ Me (5C)/Q[8] (-88.75 kJ mol -1 ) indicated that a larger number of  cavity-bound  water  molecules  were  displaced  by  those novel host-guest binding modes. Therefore, the 2:2, 2:3, and U-shaped 1:2 binding modes  of guests with Q[8] were reasonably confirmed by the ITC data and in agreement with the  related 1 H  NMR  titration  experiment.  Additionally,  the binding constants ( K a ) for the guests and Q[8] complexes were found  to  be  between  1.0  ×  10 5   M -1   and  9.0  ×  10 6 M -1 , indicating strong host-guest binding. View Article Online DOI: 10.1039/D0QO00649A

Fluorescence  lifetime  data  systematically  determined  by time-correlated  single  photon  counting  (TCSPC)  was  fully  in line with the above observations. As shown in Table S2, after addition  of  Q[8]  to  the  relevant  guest  solution,  the  lifetime was significantly increased (in the range of 7 to 15 ns), except in the case of the 1:2 complex (guest/Q[8]) and all host-guest interactions  of OPV 2+ -2Me (7C-9C)  where  shorter  lifetimes were observed. The longest fluorescence lifetimes were observed  for  the  2:3  complexes  of  Q[8]  with  the  5C-6Cappended OPV 2+ -H and OPV 2+ -Me guests.  Essentially,  longer lifetimes imply that the π-conjugated OPV 2+ core (fluorophore) is deeply encapsulated  in the Q[8] cavity, while shorter lifetimes indicate that the fluorophore is less deeply buried or further from the Q[8] cavity. 39 Most importantly, the fluorescence lifetime changes were fully in line with the hostguest  assembly  modes  confirmed  by  the  fluorescence  and NMR spectra,  suggesting  that  fluorescence  decay  times  may have  potential  in  the  characterization  of  Q[8]-chromophore systembinding modes. In particular, the solubility limit of the Q[8] host and the intrinsic hydrophobic effect of the chromophore in water sometimes hinder the performance of the  NMR  titration  experiment.  For  example,  in  the  present work,  the  poor  solubility  of OPV 2+ -2Me (7C-9C)  in  aqueous solution  meant  that  the  NMR  signal  changes  were  not  clear enough  to  detail  the  host-guest  interactions.  The  shorter fluorescence lifetimes from these complexes in dilute solution, however, gave strong supplementary evidence to support the host-guest binding modes.
In addition to the above, the Q[8]-derived dynamic hostguest assemblies and the fluorescent signals, such as those of the OPV 2+ -Me (5C)/Q[8] complex, can be used as competitive fluorescent indicator displacement chemosensors for the discrimination of spermine and spermidine from other species such  as  cations,  anions  and  amino  acids  in  pure  aqueous solution  (Fig.  S14).  This  suggests  that  Q[8]-based  dynamic assemblies and their resulting fluorescent signals have further applications.

In  summary,  we  have  successfully  prepared  a  series  of  Q[8]derived multiple dynamic host-guest assemblies, including 2:2, 2:3, and 1:2 complexes, that exhibited quantitative fluorescence. These signals were not only sensitively captured in the  fluorescence  spectra,  but  could  also  be  visualized directly  using  the  naked  eye  under  UV  light.  The  host-guest binding modes were further characterized by their 1D and 2D NMR  spectra.  Interestingly, the systematically determined fluorescence lifetimes obtained  from  the  Q[8]  complexes indicated  that  they  could  be  used  to  help  characterize  the host-guest  binding  modes.  Most  importantly,  the  Q[8]-based dynamic assemblies induced by N-substituted alkyl chains and subtle  modification  by  Me  groups  on  the OPV 2+ core  had different binding properties according to their HSCT interactions. These dynamic assemblies included the 2:3 quinary  complex  and  the  1:2  interaction-triggered  U-shaped conformation have not been reported previously. We expect that  the  Q[8]-based  new  binding  fashionsand  the  resulting photophysical  properties  will  help  to  extend  application  of Q[8]  as  a  macrocyclic  host  in  supramolecular  polymers  and functional materials.
